findings.title: Flashloan Attack
findings.description: When working with exchange rates, they should be received from a trusted source and not be vulnerable to short-term rate changes that can be achieved by using flash loans. Oracles should be used.

findings.title: Token Supply manipulation
findings.description: Tokens can be minted only according to rules specified in a whitepaper or any other documentation provided by the customer.

findings.title: Wrong indexes.
findings.description: Token indexes are inconsistent and can cause additional complexity to the smart contract code and systems that will use those contracts.

findings.title: DoS (Denial of Service)
findings.description: Execution of the code should never be blocked by a specific contract state unless it is required.

findings.title: Wrong pre-sale detection algorithm.
findings.description: If the pre-sale period is active, then the public sale time has come, and pre-sale period should end automatically. However, it will not. Therefore all users who did not have time to buy a token during the pre-sale period are still eligible to buy the token. The problem is “&&” operator has a higher priority than “||” operator.

findings.title: Style guide violation
findings.description: Style guides and best practices should be followed.

findings.title: Gas Limit and Loops
findings.description: Transaction execution costs should not depend dramatically on the amount of data stored on the contract. There should not be any cases when execution fails due to the block gas limit.

findings.title: Tests Coverage
findings.description: The code should be covered with unit tests. Tests coverage should be 100%, with both negative and positive cases covered.
